author: ebilbrey

title: Walther Lever Action CO2 Pellet Rifle Buttplate

description.text: A thinner buttplate for the Walther Lever Action CO2 pellet rifle. This thinner buttplate reduces the length of the stock by about 1 inch. Suited only for the new model which uses 88g CO2 cartridges. Instead of protruding metal pins, this buttplate has a hemispherical cavity, which fits snugly over the end of the CO2 cartridge.

Print using your favorite 3D printer. I printed mine in black PLA, with a wall thickness of 1.5mm, and 25% infill density. I wasn't sure about the overhang in the large hemispherical cavity, but it printed fine on both exemplars I made.  
You will also need an M6 screw with a conical head, and a total length of 30mm.

comments.text:
Only recently did I discover that not all 88g CO2 cylinders are created equal!
Be aware that this thinner butt plate might not work with your brand of cylinder.
Short enought to work: Beretta
Too long: Umarex

That's right, it's a parametric panoramic egg, just in time for Easter!
A panoramic egg is a festive egg-shaped sugar-based confection that has a little window in it with a small sugar-formed Easter scene inside.  These are typically very labor and time intensive to create.

Either edit the OpenSCAD file to suit or make use of the exploitable panoramic egg STL.  For some reason the OpenSCAD file looks very different when compiled.  In any case, please put something cool inside the egg and upload it as a derivative!

description.text:
Similar stands for protein purification from Promega and Millipore cost anywhere from $45-377 (for 8 position stands).  That's ludicrous!  It is plastic with a neodymium magnet inside.  So I designed my own and printed it out in about 25 minutes (total cost around $2, including the rare earth magnet inside).  The stand is sized to fit two 3/4" x 1/2" by 1/4" rectangular magnets, although the space should accommodate and work perfectly with other smaller/rounder rare earth magnets.  It is also designed to be modular, in that the first prototype here fits together with tape, such that you can transform the two-position stand into a four-position stand by removing the tape.  
I am happy to hear your comments, questions, and to see if anyone else can derive a better unit.  I plan on quickly designing an 8-position unit sometime in the near future (per request, to replace the Millipore unit).
Print two of these babies, insert rare earth magnets, and tape 'em together.

author: EfimoMax

description.text:
For use with RPG games and wargames. The outside measures 3.5 inches by 2 3/8 inches. Inside, it is large enough to fit six miniatures with 25mm bases, or a 50mm (large) base figure plus two 25mm figures.  
I placed the parts separately, for if you want a set of bars to resize to fit into a 1" to 4" opening, it can easily be resized in something like 123D to your needs.  
I made the walls separate, in case someone only wants one wall of either type, and made a version without the top "cap," to allow you to choose your look. The full cage will print the bottom, but no top - for that print a floor separately.  
I've added a 2" wide, shorter bar wall for use with Dwarven Forge, Open Forge, Dungeon Stone, and Hirst Arts style terrain. This added STL file has a 1/2" deep pair of outer walls, so it'll stand up on its own, and could be printed numerous times to make custom cage shapes on the table.
Original pieces created in 123 Max. Run through netfabb basic to repair any holes.

title: Parameterized Vertical Carriage for Kossel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Edit: I have now added a GT2 belt clamp so the motors can be in the middle as well! I also added some simple boolean variables in the .scad file to enable/disable what to use. What I find work here is to put in both ends into the clamp, and then tighten it with a m3 screw. Seems to hold it quite well! Then, to tighten the belt, you just move the top up. This is the paramereized version of the Cerberus pup vertical carriage you can find here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ypm4oHYM4Uo and here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_Mn4U0srZGg I got the original from Steve (thanks Steve!), but wanted to add belt support as well. So I figured I do it with OpenSCAD. There really shouldn't be much to change, as it should be pretty tweaked and ready to use as is. Still, I like having it in .scad format. Works superb on Openbeam! The Dual 623 V Roller from http://3d.grabercars.com/?product=11-delrin-roller-with-608-bearing-fits-1515-series-extrusion-from-8020-net-copy really makes this excellent! I also love the tightener design. Furthermore, I added support for belts, using a clamp. Since I have a few of those Openbeam brackets, I also needed to put that belt on the side, which is why I also have that "belt holder" which can be screwed on the side and can be seen in the images attatched here. So, with this, it's up to you to use fishing line, or a belt. And, the belt can be either in the middle or on the side using the belt holder.

Well, print it. Then you need a bunch of M3 screws. And, you need 3 Dual 623 V Rollers per carriage, ending up in 9 in total for all three.  
I also have a nut between the plastic and the dual 623 V roller to add some necessarily spacing.

author: Chillance

description.text: Use this mount to adapt a dial indicator to your DaVinci 2.0 Duo 3D Printer.It's flimsy and inaccurate but its a start

WARNING: REMOVE FROM UNIT BEFORE PRINTING OR CALIBRATING.
Calibration on the DaVinci Duo is a painful task and usually requires several cycles to obtain a suitable calibration. I made this to help in taking out some of the guesswork.
It's a little flimsy, does not cover all the bed and doesn't hook on securely, but it's a start. I'm not yet shooting for a particular specification, it is just used to verify and adjust the print bed with fewer calibration cycles.
I originally had it mounted to the top on the bracket but didn't have an extension for my indicator so had to move it to the face.
I purchased the Dial indicator from Harbor Freight tools for 14.99, a pretty good deal. This is for the Duo, but with some easy modifications it could be easily made to work with the other XYZPrinting units as well. I have included the Sketchup file for your modding enjoyment.

title: Solidoodle 3 fan duct/mount for E3D v6 upgade w/ OE extruder housing

description.text:
I used the OE extruder housing to mount the E3D extruder after I found out that the one I had printed out wasn't the right one (wasn't labeled for a specific version). It also moves the CG closer to the center. This duct takes a 40mm fan by whatever depth you want.  
NOTE: If you are about to upgrade, you need to get and print my endstop too for the X-axis.  
Update: Looks like I need to add a second axis duct-fan mount or bolt hole design to better secure the duct to the mount. It works great as is, it's just for greater rigidity.

I suggest printing in a material with a higher glass transition temp like nylon, PET+, PETG (not 100% sure on that since I haven't used it and don't know the specs), ABS just for those prints that don't use the fan. I used PET+. I'm printing it now, but the previous versions come out nice @0.2mm layer height. This has angles =<45deg with thin walls so slow down your print if the walls aren't holding up or for increased bonding strength. Uses 8mm magnets (bought mine at home depot).  
No supports needed for the duct.  
Supports needed for the mount.

title: BB-8 Star Wars Ball Droid remix for Sphero (or just as a stand alone toy)

description.text:
We made this model before this toy came out: http://amzn.to/21Jlv6O But even if you don't have a Sphero lying around this model can create a fun printable toy. 2015-09-30 UPDATE: Added STL versions in a zipped archive for download. IF I HAD THE TIME: I would create a custom "top guide", for the 3 pronged part inside the sphero, for two magnets to sit in and keep the head facing forward. or I would create a weighted piece that replaces Sphero. Maybe someone else wants to take on either challenge (someone without a full time job, kids, and a honey-do-list). Working from Lilykill's great model the base has been re-scaled and sliced in to halves for convenience and easy use with a Sphero. NOTE for perfectionist: I scaled up the base slightly to 74mm which makes the outer diameter of the base a little larger than the original Sphero but it better matches the inner diameter of the original and seems to make the robot move more freely. This first version requires you to cut the Sphero open and glue a magnet to inner 3 prong top guide. NOTE: I've tried a couple of different magnet combinations and haven't found the perfect mix or placement. (more detail later) Also included is a version of the head for resin printers. It is hollow with two drain holes at the bottom. Some fun testing with the kids:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n-jPV6X17ss
Built using resources from the Ross School's Innovation Lab.

Still unsure of the best way to print this and I imagine it will depend on your printer... but I've printed the head of this on a Ultimaker 2 in white PLA and had some really nice prints with just a brim. I have tried the half sphere with just a brim but the inner top area was too rough for the Sphero's tight tolerances and he/she would get stuck. I have also been able to print it on a Form1+ in white resin with some success but I'm not convinced the quality is worth the trouble in this case. The trick is printing it and having a really smooth interior so the Sphero can spin freely inside.

title: Sacrificial vise covers for Carbide3d Nomad Vise

description.text: I just purchased a vise from Carbide3d to go with their Nomad 883 CNC mill. It works well, but on my first print, the cutter came very close to the clamps on the vice. I designed these covers for the vise to print on a 3-d printer - this way, they serve as a sacrificial vice face - if the cutter starts spewing black shreds of plastic, I'll know I'm getting too close! The covers are a tight fit, to prevent sliding. Made with Cheetah3d, so that's what the .jas file is.

description.text:
This egg cup is a result of a request from a gold and silversmith to make the ideal egg cup. Originally the idea was to design something that had the spoon and salt in it, so you couldn't forget it.  
My idea was to make it in 14 karat gold and that would be enough reason not to forget the spoon and salt as they were also designed in 14 karat gold B-)  
The design has no filled on the edges, which makes it look thin expensive and elegant.

This object was made in Autodesk 123D Design as a non-technical thingy. The Helix (as it is not an option within the program) is created by creating a loft of rectangles 30 degree steps and intersecting it with an egg.  
You can create an L class egg (4.5cm x 6cm) to combine a circle with an ellipse. One of the remarkable things in nature is the mathematical formula behind the simplest things.

Based on the 1st generation of Artifex 3D Printer, the Artifex 2 comes with a redesigned extrusion mechanism to handle both flexible materials (e.g., NinjaFlex) and standard rigid materials (e.g., PLA, ABS) in one extruder without tool change. The Artifex 2 also offers other new features, including dual extrusion capability (Artifex 2 Duo version), LCD controller for untethered printing and on-board control, and other enhancements. Both fully assembled and DIY kit packages are available at http://www.3dmakerworld.com/store/3dprinters. Slic3r and Cura configuration files are provided for various settings at http://www.3dmakerworld.com/support/downloads. Some printing videos:
  • Printing two color earth: https://youtu.be/GClik0iL17M
  • Printing NinjaFlex: https://youtu.be/vXWkbZxkXrA
  • Printing scale-up T-Rex skull: https://youtu.be/FmZ-FKjYYk8
See the attached Build Instructions and User Manual.

Loosely remixed from Parametric Spool Hub by hdonk http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28046. The primary reason for the remix was to correct issues with the mesh between the spokes and the hub. Provisions have been added to chamfer the edges that insert into the filament spool, and the number of cylinder facets is now factored from the diameter of the adapter. For ease of use and tailoring by others, the openSCAD script has also been extensively commented. The STL provided is just a sample output, rendering a spool adapter 52mm diameter with an axle hole of 8mm. Other sizes are possible through changes to the parameter definitions in the openSCAD script. The gallery picture also just shows some of the variations of spool adapters created with the script.
Edit the openSCAD script for the spool adapter characteristics needed.  Create the STL file from openSCAD.  Print.  Use.

title: Kyosho Mini-Z Ferrari 458 Italia GT2 Front Body Mount

description.text: Time for another 3D printable replacement for Mini-Z, a front body mount for Ferrari 458 Italia GT2. You can use this body mount for your Kyosho Mini-Z RC model if your stock front body mount breaks and you are having trouble finding a replacement for the Ferrari 458 Italia GT2 body. The body holder should be a perfect fit and provide enough strength and durability, just like the original one. We recommend to use 0.1mm layer height for best results and the use of support structure as some part of the body mount is in the air and it will not be useable if don't use supports. Designed by http://minirc-project.com/

A set of printable pieces that allow you to play Michael Schoessow's excellent 2 player abstract Alien City. boardgamegeek link: https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/20623/alien-city piecepack page:
http://www.ludism.org/ppwiki/AlienCity

You will need at least 5 colors to print this game, or you will need to paint all these pieces
after printing. In a neutral color (Black or grey):
5 copies of [tiles-4.stl] for 20 total tiles
1 copy of [flags-set.stl] for 3 flags each of two different types.
--Print these in a 6th color if you have one. In Color A
1 copy of [dagan-structures.stl]
1 copy of [road-set.stl] In Color B
1 copy of [vshori-structures.stl]
1 copy of [road-set.stl] In Color C
1 copy of [hayan-structures.stl]
1 copy of [road-set.stl] In Color D
1 copy of [malsak-structures.stl]
1 copy of [road-set.stl] Slot all the printed roads into the depressions in the tiles, and find a box to throw everything
into. Congrats, you've got an Alien City!

An adapter to swap out the 1.2V NiCd cells in your BP7217 Battery pack used in many Fluke instruments like DSP-100

Print the adapter.
use carefully a knife to cut between the flat part of the pack and the curved half. there is used silicone glue on the flat part glued to the NiCd cells them selves.
connect the AA batteries the same way and remember to use the thermal fuse as a jumper like used on the NiCd cells. do not throw this away.
Terminals made from pieces of Steel Strap packing bands. Terminals fixed with glue gun on the terminals solder together the bent parts making it both a spring and a contact point. securing the batteries with just i bit of glue gun

I know people have already experimented with this a bit but I thought it would be nice to have a slightly more elegant solution to the problem of mounting a pen or pencil or brush or whatever to the Makerbot (before I had just hot-glued a marker to my extruder).
*Just updated it with an extra piece that you can print and strap on with rubber bands that allows the pen/tool to travel slightly, allowing better contact with the surface. It does this while still allowing the pen to be picked up off of the surface when you need to start a new line.

Print out two of each. Assemble with 2 m3x30mm and 2 m3x16mm (or whatever works).
*for the extra addition print out two vsidetop's and clamp together around the top of the pen with 2 m3x30mm's. reduce the tension in the main body to allow the pen to slide up and down and attach the top with rubber bands.
I have yet to really mess around with the g-code * it to draw cool things (will definitely have to try TMR's parametric stuff sometime) but from my work with the frostruder editing the G-code shouldn't be too daunting.

author: rkloehnig3

description.text: A name banner for Cortlynn.

This is a model of a Bench.  
The goal was to make the model printable in one piece and without the need of any support material.

During the initial build of the i3v printer, I cut away the upper left corner of the x-idler mounting plate in order to provide better fit alongside the right-side z-nut bracket. In replacing the stock z-nut brackets with RickSisco's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:769057, I wanted a new plate without the trimmed corner. Two STL versions of the x-idler plate are provided. One is 48mm long, a direct replacement for the stock wood plate. The other is 60mm long, which covers the two horizontal v-rails completely and may provide a better mechanical installation for the x-idler. The plate leverages the roundCornersCube script from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812 to provide the option for round corners on the plate. The provided STL files were created with the corner radius set to 2mm.

If generating new STL from openSCAD, download the roundCornersCube script from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812 and copy it to where ever you put other custom library scripts. The i3v_x_idler_plate script assumes the use of a Custom folder in the openSCAD library area; modify the path location as necessary. Print the bracket plate with a high amount of infill in order to provide a rigid mount for the x-idler and to withstand the compression from the idler mounting bolts.

This is a crooked vase (weights on the left) that can be customized with anyone's initials (or other design).  
The "weighted vase" file builds the vase and leaves a hole to be filled with coins, screws, fishing weights--whatever.  The "cap" to the weight hole is the "wp" file, for someone whose initials are "W.P."  
To create your own file, make a block 38 mm wide, 30 mm high, 40 mm deep and carve out what you don't want. I used the spline curve and extruded excess away with 123d software.  
Build at 30% infill--I used supports.  
To connect the vase and the initials together, I used an old soldering iron to melt the PLA together.  You could use superglue--or acetone if using ABS plastic.

comments.text: i would write WTF instead of initials  XD

title: Connection Ball Thingy
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
No, it's not a naval mine, although the design is probably ideal for detonation at aft ship rather than at the bow. The "Connection Ball" is a result of an impossible design task to create a new joint for 20mm x 20mm square profiles / pipes ?!? The term "NEW" gave me a headache for a week. The Ball / Mine has 30, 60, 45, 90 degree sockets and all other angles possible HOW TO USE:
-The cross is inserted
  • turned clockwise
  • pulled upwards
  • locked by the cuff (threated)
  • the inside pin is pushed upwards (space for spring is available)
  • The cross will lock the thingy at the end.
    • I decided to upload it, because we will probably have to wait for a way to convert energy into solids, before we can print this model in metal. I invite you to proof me wrong :-) Please contact me if you need the high resolution model. I will try to upload it...
I started and couldn't stop... while I had other important things to do :-/

comments.text: This thingy might soon be printer as an example of what a powder printer can do.

Print a few- build a skatepark! Thanks Sketchasaurus!!!

remixed_from.title: i3v push fit belt guide v1

title: MakerFarm i3v X or Y idler belt pulley for 12mm bearings

description.text: This is a remix of Zen1's i3v push fit belt guide from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:359773, leveraging an enhanced version of the original source openSCAD script from Parametric Pulley, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627. The pulley can be used for either the x-axis or y-axis idler in the MakerFarm i3v printer. Changes to the thing:359773 design include increasing the pulley_t_ht parameter from 6.2 to 6.5mm to provide more room for the belt fit; decreasing the idler_ht and retainer_ht parameters from 1.4 to 0.75mm to provide an overall width of 8mm for a better fit on (2) 4-mm wide bearings; increased the additional_tooth_depth parameter from 0 to 0.1mm to help ensure the belt isn't just riding on the compressible teeth of the belt; and increased the number of teeth from 25 to 26 to provide slightly more body between the bearing hole and the teeth (a print quality improvement). The primary change to the openSCAD source from thing:16627 is to provide for chamfer on the shaft hole - very helpful in inserting the i3v 12mm OD bearings. Other changes include migrating to use of MCAD library polyhole for improved dimensioning of holes.

Quality of the printed teeth on the pulley is important. Inspect the printed result for good tooth shape, minimal stringing, etc.  Especially with PLA, manage print thermal issues with a print cooler, by printing multiple parts at the same time, or other technique.  
To install the pulley, press-fit the (2) 5x12x4mm MakerFarm idler bearings into the pulley.  Fully inserted, the bearings should be flush with the sides of the pulley.  Mount the idler pulley to the i3v using the M5 hardware provided with the MakerFarm i3v kit.

author: Printbus

title: Configurable OpenSCAD Square Tubing Connector Generator

description.text:
This is mostly a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14061. I just streamlined the SCAD code a bit, and added options for all possible orthogonal permutations (up to 6 tubes per connector). Should be easily scalable, though I've only tested it on 1" aluminum tubing. Comes with a test finger option, so you can dial in your desired fit without wasting a lot of time and plastic. I will post links to things made with this SCAD file soon. WARNING: FOR LIGHT DUTY ONLY!
The obvious use is for storage racks/shelving, but use some common sense with your load and application. The fingers will shear off if you overload them. Don't go building scaffolding or bookshelves with them. For photos of an actual thing built with these connectors, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1103635

Simply comment out or uncomment the finger variables to select the number and orientation of the tubing connections you want to render in OpenSCAD, then export your .stl for printing.  I recommend printing a short test finger first to make sure the dimensions work with your tubing and print setup.  Tweak as needed or desired.  When test fitting, be sure to deburr your tubing carefully, or fit will seem tighter than it really is.  
I am printing at 0.2mm layer, 50% infill with good results.  Higher infill would obviously be stronger.  You will need support for any fingers in the x-y plane of your print bed.  Be sure support is positioned under each vein in the finger surface facing your print bed, or you will wind up with twisted veins and possibly a ruined print (S3D gets this wrong without help).  I print exclusively in ABS, so I can't comment on other materials.  PLA seems like a bad idea for this application.

The table in my workshop/man cave was in desperate need of some cable management. The best way I could see fixing this problem is by running some of my cables down through the desk. The only issue with this is that I would then have a huge ugly hole in the middle of my desk. So this was the good news moment of my day. Good News: I had a white 2â€³ desk gromit I could use to fill the hole and class things up a bit.
Bad News: My desk is black. I had some black ABS already loaded in my Thing-o-Matic so I took the next logical step and reached for my digital caliper to get modeling. In about 15 minutes I was able to make a nearly exact scale model of my white desk gromit in Google Sketchup. You can read more about my design process in this blog post:
http://www.thenewhobbyist.com/2011/04/everyday-fixes-with-makerbot-1-desk-gromit/

The top fits snuggly into the base without being too hard to remove. It actually holds on a little better than the store bought model. 
This model can be scaled up or down to fit various hole sizes, the full size model will fit a 2 inch hole.
I've also included my SketchUp model if you would like to make modifications beyond scaling.

description.text: This provides an improved mount for attaching the x-axis belt to the x-carriage on MakerFarm i3v-series printers. One concern with the OEM mounting approach is possible flex in the M3 mounting screws, especially if the screws loosen or wear into the i3v wood carriage plate. Another concern is that wrapping the belt around the M3 screws could lead to backlash/ripple as the belt rocks on the belt teeth, or as the teeth compress during acceleration and then slack later. The improved mount bolts to the x-carriage using the same mounting holes in the x-carriage plate. The belt ends wrap around form-fit posts that should help minimize concerns with the belt teeth rocking or compressing. Clips on the belt keep the belt snug, and a cover plate ensures the clips and belt remain secure, as well as providing reinforcement against the belt posts flexing under strain. The gallery picture shows the mount without the cover installed. The mount repositions the x-belt slightly rearward from typical installations. A 5mm ID shim spacer is provided that can be used to reposition the i3v x-idler bearings/pulley by a similar amount. Thickness of the shim spacer has been optimized for use with my remix of the i3v idler pulley available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790138. The formed posts the belts wrap around are created using the Parametric Pulley openSCAD script from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16627. The mounting plate and cover leverage the roundCornersCube openSCAD script from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812. Detailed instructions are in the openSCAD file. Note that this mount does require longer length belt than would have been originally used in the i3v. The i3v presents challenges in alternatives for the x-belt mount. If the belt connection is too high, the belt or the mount can rub on the upper horizontal aluminum v-rail. If the belt connection point is too low, it adds an angle effect to the belt that will become more pronounced as the x-carriage approaches the x-idler or the x-motor. This mount lowers the belt connection from the OEM approach just the thickness of the flat base of the belt, or about 0.75mm. This is intended as a complement to the y-axis belt mount available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:796250.

Detailed instructions are also provided in the i3v_xbelt_mount script. Quality of the formed belt posts is important. Inspect the printed mount for properly shaped teeth and for minimal stringing between teeth. This is a structural part, so print with an adequate number of perimeters and infill percentage (my parts were printed with 3 perimeters and 50% infill using Simplify3D as the slicer). If generating the mount from openSCAD, script i3v_xbelt_mount.scad is the primary file. It in turn will import the formed belt post under the filename belt_post.stl. The belt_post.stl file provided was generated using Parametric Pulley from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8812 configured as follows (other parameter values shouldn't affect the results):
  • teeth = 12; // Number of teeth
  • profile = 12; // 12=GT2_2mm
  • motor_shaft = 0; // shaft will be bored here
  • retainer = 0; // No belt retainer flange above teeth
  • retainer_ht = 0; // height of retainer flange is zero
  • idler = 0; // No belt retainer flange below teeth
  • idler_ht = 0; // height of idler flange is zero
  • pulley_t_ht = 6 + 0.02; // width of belt plus a bit extra for mesh overlap
  • pulley_b_ht = 0; // pulley base height is zero

title: Small spool holder adjustable with magnets

description.text: I love how the thing:93652 is a great, simple, flexible and very low-drag spool holder. I had been using it for a while just next to the printer, until recently, when I decided to move the spool of filament within the printer's enclosure, since there is enough space for it on my XYZ Da Vinci 1.0. At just about the same time I bought some new filaments, and these came with spools of smaller width than I had before, so I thought of a quick and frictionless way to adjust the position of the rollers to match the varying size of the spools. Since my printer's floor is metallic, I figured that the best solution would be -guess what- Yeah Bitch! Magnets! So this remix adds holes to attach 4 round magnets of 14mm diameter to the rollers. I used some pretty powerful ones that I had lying around and they provide a really strong fix. The roller definitely won't move unless I want it to! Additionally, some of the new spools came pretty full, like almost overflowing, and this wasn't working well as the original design of the spool holder as when there is so much filament it does not provide enough clearance to spin properly. So I've also created an asymmetrical version (also available with and without magnets) which has a much lower tab on one side, and this fixes the issue elegantly while still keeping the spool in place.

Follow the original instructions in thing:93652 for assembling the bearings. I'd recommend printing it with a high infill rate (or even directly 100%) to make it strong. I used PLA for mines, which helped with the warping (this design does tend to warp a lot in the corners). If you are using the version with magnets here are a few tips:
  • Print it with a small brim. You may then remove it from the outer edges but leave it intact on the inside of the circles. This will help the magnets to stay in place, unless you've glued them, in which case that would not be necessary.
  • I only printed one of the rollers with magnets while the other one is the magnet-less version and it's simply fixed to the floor with double-sided tape. This way I only have to adjust the position of one of them.
  • Use a pen or a fine marker to draw some marks in the exact position where the roller should be for each spool size you will be handling. This will make the spool switching process even quicker.

title: FrSky Antenna Clamp (for X-series Rx PCB diversity antennas)

description.text:
Yet another FrSky two-part dual antenna mount.  There are several similar designs here, but none of them had quite the mounting orientation I wanted, and I couldn't find one with source code attached, so I coded this from scratch in OpenSCAD.  
I get Rx RSSI telemetry on my Tx, and values are significantly higher with this mount on my X-quad.  My old mounting arrangement was closer to horizontal plane, with no means to keep the relative orientation of the two PCBs orthogonal.  A worthwhile and simple upgrade.  Looks neat too.  Should snap off in a crash.  
I have included .stl files for both parts.  The dimensions are tested and optimized.  They hold my X8R antennas very securely with just one clamp screw (a 10mm M3 socket head and nut are required).  Chances are you will want a different mounting geometry too, but the good news is that I'm posting the OpenSCAD generator, so you can revise or get rid of my simple side-mounting tab as you like.  You can revise the clamp dimensions as well.  I coded all primary dimensions as global variables.  The SCAD file will render either part by commenting or uncommenting variable defines.  See the file for instructions.

This prints great and fairly quickly in ABS at 0.1 or 0.2 mm, 100% infill.  Any other setup, and you are on your own.  Dimensions optimized for IC3D black ABS filament.  You may need to tweak some dimensions to suit your setup or filament, but it is a cheap one to dial in.  Installation is pretty foolproof, just be careful not to pinch the wires when tightening the clamp screw.  
If you do use my mounting tab geometry, the tab doubles as a nut trap.  It will take a little force to get the M3 nut into the trap on part 1.  Put the part flat on the table, align nut with hexagonal hole, angled down below the tab (use tweezers if you have dubious manual dexterity like me), then press the raised edge firmly with a flat-bladed screwdriver.  It will pop in, and it will not come back out.  If you want your nut back, you will have to break the tab off.  If your nuts are bigger than mine (cue laugh track), you can always add a few microns of clearance to the hexagon (in line 67 of the SCAD file, change the 0.05 to 0.06 say).  I tested this procedure on several prototypes though, and it always worked for me.  
EDIT 8/30/2015:  Revised mounting tab code for more intuitive parameterization and rescaling without blocking nut trap.

author: kapudon

description.text:
As we tend to use a lot less in this age where media is more commonly consumed in its pure digital form, we tend to have less reliance on physical media anymore. This is a pity as some CDs and DVDs do come with such spectacular art, and are now just doomed to be trapped in must CD cases. So the CD Stem was created as simple and meaningful way for collectors who still treasure having the physical discs to display and showcase their collection. More about this over in a post here:
http://funbiestudios.com/2013/04/cd-stem-project/ If you would like to get a piece also and support us, here's the link to hit up:
http://funbiestudios.com/shop/featured-products/cd-stem.html
This piece can be printed out without support, with better results at layer heights 0.2mm and below.

Front bumper coming soon This is a light bar for 250 H-frame style quad. It will hold a six LED strip of lights. The holes on the bar portion are wire passthroughs to afford the connections a little bit of protection and strain-relief; same as the other square holes. The flat portion is meant to fit between the two bottom plates of the quad. The hole spacing should fit a variety of brands and you reuse the screws that attach the plates to the posts. Its size is 112mm L x 10.5 H. The flat portion's width is 50mm at its widest point and is 3mm thick. I can make a 5mm is there is interest 100mm of the total length was necessary to fit six LEDs.

Printer:

Chinese knockoff

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes: Specs, as listed, utilize a 0.4mm nozzle.

Sketchup Necessity is the mother of invention, and I wanted something to act as a rear bumper, support LED lights and be easy to install; integrating itself into the pre-existing frame structures and utilizing hardware already used within the frame.
I printed mine at 50% infill, 2 perimeters, 0.2 layer height, 0.4 nozzle. Using PLA at those specs the final weight is 8.4 grams.

This is a flattened image of the sloth life meme. It is a monochrome print that looks great with a little bit of love and paint after it's completed. The piece shown in the examples was printed in PLA in 'fast' quality on an Ultimaker2. Three pieces are printed and assembled using model glue.   
NOTE - 4/24/15, Updated the supports and base to be in scale with the full sized sloth.

• Print all three pieces
  • Paint, if you so desire, the sloth. For a simple pop outline the edges with a marker
  • You may need to sand the support beams a little so they'll fit in the base.
  • Glue the support beams into the base.
  • Glue the base assembly onto the back of the sloth.
